Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Alteration of mantle peridotite: Geochemical fluxes and dynamics of far from equilibrium transport
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves an interdisciplinary study of hydration, carbonation and oxidation of mantle peridotite interacting with aqueous fluids at temperatures below ~ 300C. The PIs will combine observations of outcrops and boreholes, geochemical analyses, structural measurements, geomechanical experiments and numerical modeling to investigate feedback between alteration and fluid transport, and to quantify the resulting geochemical fluxes. Field observations and sampling will take place mainly in the Samail ophiolite of Oman, where peridotite has undergone spreading-ridge-related hydrothermal alteration, hydration and carbonation in the hanging-wall of the subduction zone that emplaced the ophiolite over metasediments, and subaerial weathering. The PIs project will provide matching funds and results that dovetail with the 2015-2018 International Continental Scientific Drilling Program (ICDP) Oman Drilling Project, and the many other related efforts just getting underway. The PIs will continue their independently supported research on subduction zone alteration of mantle wedge peridotites at a range of pressures and temperatures, and work closely with other groups investigating seafloor and subduction-related peridotite alteration, in order to quantify the similarities and differences in alteration processes in these different tectonic environments. They will generalize their results to global alteration processes and geochemical cycles.

Alteration of peridotite is an essential process in Earth dynamics. Hydration of oceanic crust and mantle, followed by subduction, supplies water to drive arc volcanism, and modulates the hydrogen content of the mantle over time. Carbonate formation during alteration of peridotite, near the surface and in the hanging wall in subduction zones, is an important but poorly characterized link in the carbon cycle. Oxidation of minerals and concomitant reduction of fluids produces H2 and hydrocarbons, and a niche for chemosynthetic microbes. Chemical weathering is as important as magmatism and plate tectonics in shaping the Earths surface. The interplay of chemical and physical mechanisms of peridotite alteration is not well understood, but will be transformed as a result of emerging understanding of equilibria and kinetics in peridotite alteration, and reaction-driven cracking that has left us poised on the brink of a breakthrough at this little-studied frontier. The PIs will take advantage of low temperature, near surface, active peridotite alteration in Oman to study inputs, outputs, and the reaction zone in situ. Such a study is more difficult in smaller peridotite exposures with limited outcrop and more rainfall, nearly impossible in submarine hydrothermal systems, and completely impossible in studies of ancient systems. Such a comprehensive approach via 250 to 600 meter boreholes is very rare, if not unprecedented.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our role in this collaborative project was to conduct computer calculations to model the consequences of reactions at ambient, low-temperatures involving rainwater with geologic materials from the Earth?s upper mantle that are exposed in the mountains of the Sultanate of Oman. The resulting process is called serpentinization, owing to the production of serpentine minerals as a result of alteration. This process also dramatically changes the composition of the water, raising the pH extraordinarily and driving the production of hydrogen from water.

 

Intellectual Merit: We developed quantitative thermodynamic models of the serpentinization process in general, and models that are specific to the conditions in Oman. In the general modeling we show how the alteration of upper mantle materials at the low temperatures of the Earth?s surface simultaneously produce new minerals in the rocks and dramatic changes in the composition of the water. The new minerals that form allow the iron, magnesium and silicon in the upper mantle rocks to rearrange into new crystalline forms, but those new minerals exclude calcium present in the original materials. The calcium stays dissolved in the water, and as a consequence the pH of the water increases. Essentially, rain water is converted to a calcium hydroxide solution resembling a dilute solution of lye. Our models explicitly account for each step in this process. They also reveal the sequence of events in which water is reduced to hydrogen by oxidation of iron in the mantle rocks. Unlike previous models, we find that much of this oxidation-reduction process happens during the formation of the serpentine minerals, rather than from the production of iron oxide minerals. Furthermore, our results quantify the conditions at which various carbonate minerals form during the serpentinization process. In the modeling specific to Oman, we use our analytical data from water samples collected in Oman, together with all other Oman water data reported in scientific papers, in explanations specific to the alteration processes there. We also explain all water compositions that result from mixing of water that has undergone the serpentinization process with surface water derived from precipitation. Furthermore, we predict how water compositions change and show how many samples from wells represent stages of the overall alteration process or resulting subsurface mixing with infiltrating surface water. These modeling efforts are the most complete general characterization ever attempted of low-temperature serpentinization, and the most rigorous efforts to test modeling results against a comprehensive set of data for serpentinization from a natural system. Both the general modeling and the work specific to Oman are used to help interpret results from the Oman Drilling Project.

 

Broader Impacts: With regard to impacts in other scientific fields, results of our theoretical modeling also explain how the serpentinization process supplies sources of chemical energy that support microorganisms that live at the extreme pH conditions generated. Our results provided guidance for simultaneous studies of the composition and distribution of microbial communities in the serpentinizing systems of Oman. In addition, our models produce predictions of how chemical energy supplies are affected by mixing of surface and subsurface waters, which leads to predictions of where various types of microorganisms will be found. In terms of societal impacts, graduate research assistants were supported by funds from this grant, including one woman and one member of an underrepresented minority. The students presented posters and talks at national and international meetings, contributing to their professional development, in addition to preparing results for publication. Furthermore, their having worked with researchers from around the world contributes to international communication and understanding.
